Well, Susan, you sure blew Hank Paulson's potential intellectual standing for me by revealing that he backed the development of Canada's Tar Sands. This is my IQ test for energy and environment experts and spokes persons. If they understand the reason we don't want to refine tar sands (or oil sands) is that in the end, the gallon of refined fuel will generate almost twice as much carbon dioxide as conventional oil. The process currently used is antique and water hungry and there are no good ways known to make fuel more efficiently with Tarsands. It would be utterly stupid in terms of reducing climate change to use oil sands. My chemical engineering colleagues say that they can pump hydrogen in the field and do better.

We have to move to electric transport and solar electric power generations. We can do it. Capturing sun power in space, converting it to microwaves, beaming to Earth, and connecting to the grid is the future. It will take a while but it is feasible if we launch the components using Maglev in a vacuum launch tube, invented by my colleague James Powell and George Maise a great aerospace engineer/scientist. We are waiting for the US to wake up and realize that there is a fierce competition for space power and the US is behind. If you will, our new "sputnik".

Thanks for the Standard Marxist Perspective, but unfortunately Culturista has it right. Bohemia and to a lesser extent Budapest were thriving industrial areas before 1914. World War I began because then, as now, nations were led by men who were largely not up to the task. The leaders of Serbia, Russia, and France wanted war, and the leaders of Germany, Austria and Great Britain could not keep it from happening. What's truly interesting is that the events we see unfolding in Iraq and Syria this morning are in some sense the result of August, 1914.
The Austro-Hungarian Empire was industrialized enough to build its own battleships and other warships.

My grandparents, like yours, STG, followed that 1880s-1890s route from Hungary to America. Their reason was that everything in the country was owned by 10% of the population, with no possible upward path for peasants or the urban poor and lower middle class. It's a situation I think about a lot these days.

When Ferdinand was assassinated, Austria was one of Europe's most backward countries, still a feudal state. The Habsburgs were absolutists who deliberately barred industrialization because they believed it would empower the masses who would then become a threat to the rulers' hegemony. The collapse of the Habsburg empire was thus, in the long run, a good thing for Austria.

"folks who live in the foothills of the normal curve."

Great phrase.

It also gives us a mathematical expression for their place on the margins, just hanging on. It takes a lot of second and third standard deviations to add up to a majority. They are fighting against the math.

That's the price of security .  Live in Mexico my friend and you will thank the policemen and women of the Border Patrol and other law enforcement that they are there protecting you from narco gangsters , kidnappers , and thieving government aparachiks .

History is replete with examples of citizens who, having allowed their countries to become a police state, register collective astonishment when it inevitably turns against them.

There is no doubt that stories like this will become increasingly common.

Indeed, it would seem that the world did not really have a chance to find out what kind of government your president would try to bring to Egypt. Perhaps early reporting was too tinged with the tropes of "Islamism" and the concerns of secular democrats in your country who felt the revolution overtaken by other, less liberal agendas.

Ultimately, it seems, the real power in Egypt all along, the "Militocracy," was simply laying the ground work to re-establish its rule all along. Probably, this was in part based on convenient "accidents" of Mr. Morsi's own rule, such as the widely advertised plans to establish some form of Sharia in Egyptian law.

In any case, the "owners" in Egypt certainly are the Military, and they were not about to risk their holdings for even a well-intentioned Islamic democracy. And, actually, the world has not been silent about it. The astounding mass trials and capital sentences that the Military have inflicted on so many have not gone unnoticed.

However, it is also clear that the "owners" outside Egypt, including the American security-industrial complex, are not about to rock their own boats, especially those traveling through the Suez Canal, to save the lives of those who have inconvenienced the "owners" inside Egypt.

And, yes, this lack of concern, this total lack of empathy for the benefit of short-term gain, will end in destruction in the end. It always does.

I don't know the answer to the author's question ("Why is the world silent?"). Horrible things are happening in Egypt, and our President has met with the new dictator to "mend relations." American money most likely continues to flow to the Egyptian military. I suspect the answer may be that most people are sick to death of political Islam and believe that dictatorships are unfortunately necessary in the Middle East.  I hope the author and the journalists and the other political prisoners in Egypt finally obtain justice.

You're living in a dream. That's very different than having a dream.
If you think Morsi was democratically elect then you have no idea what democracy is. The concepts you put forward whilst in power were backwardness itself. When Morsi took all powers, a la Napoleon, he destroyed the base of democracy. End of democracy.
Another concept you may now ponder upon is Freedom. You are in the right place and surely have the time. Freedom "as per Allah word" is nothing but a way to dictatorship by those with the power to "interpret" it. Receiving orders from the terrorist brotherhood was by far the most shameful moment in Egyptian history.
In our history, a few millenniums ago, criminals were punished by being forgotten. Their names were striken out and forbidden to utter. There should be no glory for criminals. You are not going to get any. Promise.
By the way, I'm a Muslim, which I believe is none of anybody's business. I just want to make sure you will not use your innate religious racism when you read this. I'm also Egyptian French. You are a Canadian Muslim. Egypt is not in your heart.
Egypt wants to forget you....

The "World" is frequently "silent" and indifference about your plight and the plight of millions upon millions of people has no resonance among those who "own" the discourse.  The "owners'" interest is not in people and certainly not in individuals but in profit and the pursuit of profit even if, in the long-term, the end result is destruction.  Are peoples' interests served by international power politics?  Whose "interest" is served in Syria, Iraq, N.Korea, Ukraine or even in Detroit?  Not peoples' interest.
And Hobby Lobby sells oodles of things manufactured in China, where abortion is not only legal, but sometimes mandated.

um, the Greens don't seem to have any pro-choice problems with the Chinese who have a strict one child policy and who manufacture all of their products. Seems it's okay if it fits your business model to sell junk to the middle class.
"The Greens" in politics used to mean something entirely different... *sigh*

Here we go again. Republicans at election time. They've passed zero legislation that's had material, positive impact on daily American livelihood leaving them bereft of functioning achievements as examples of why voters should vote for them.

Predictably, they trot out the anti-abortion fixture, remove the vaginal probe emblem of 2012, and doll up anti-abortion in the new personhood wrapper. Same old Hollywood PR trick. Give the same old wine a new name and hawk it as the latest new hope with fresh, new phrases.

The Green's won't fund contraception because it hurts their business model. They're a big-box retailer of household decorating nick-knacks for the white, Euro-centric Christian, to create a home with the charm of grandma's 1950s tract home.

With the American, white, Euro-centric market shrinking, the Greens don't want employees, (yes, they're mostly white, Euro-centric), getting abortions and they don't want to pay for contraception to prevent pregnancies and possibly the need for abortion. They want employees having babies ... enlarging their families, and keeping their homes laden with with imported, farm-craft nick-knacks.

Latino and African-American shoppers don't find much of interest there, except maybe for the sewing supplies, but JoAnn Fabrics does that just as well and without the religious soap opera.

To really ennoble their Faith image, Hobby Lobby needs to pay livable wages. The model for that is Costco.

Ayn Rand was an immigrant who lived on welfare while she was writing her sorry paeans to narcissism.  What a glowing example for the likes of Rand Paul--a pampered mommy's boy who has never had to take responsibility for himself.  The Neo-Republican Party is a monument to irresponsibility and greed, nothing more.  In a word: evil.

Lack of education breeds ignorance, which breeds fears, which breeds irrational voters, which breeds opportunists to step in and manipulate you to vote for them. They then make millions of dollars "representing" you as they kiss the behinds of their real constituents, corporations. The only benefit you get is a regurgitation of your belief systems and the privilege of voting for the same shysters again and again. The joke's on you, America and you don't even see it as you slowly slip into serfdom.

Actually she wrote movie scripts and did quite well. For some reason she ended up on medicare at the end. But she was quite wealthy until them.

I guess it will take some research to see what happened to her estate,

"Ayn Rand chose Leonard Peikoff to be her successor as the spokesman for Objectivism. And in this brilliantly reasoned, thought-provoking work we learn why, as he demonstrates how far America has been detoured from its original path and led down the same road that Germany followed to Nazism. Self-sacrifice, Oriental mysticism, racial "truth," the public good."

He has the rights to the novels.
She smoked and ended up with either lung cancer or emphysema, I do not remember which.

As far as can be determined, she did not get welfare when she immigrated to the U.S. She wrote several small novels before the "Fountainhead" which became a widely watched movie.

His demagoguery is just despicable.
Then there are those who believe their religious beliefs are above the facts. The politicians and courts are allowing ancient beliefs to take precedence over scientific fact. In the majority of cases, these beliefs are that fairy stories written by some people living in caves by the Dead Sea, who probably never traveled more than 20 miles from there, knew more about the world and the universe, than all the scientists since.

Actually it is not just women who are under attack by these religious mentalities, it is all civilized people who they want to control, and it is a matter of control.
They want to control what you learn, your ideology, your own self view.

We might call them sons of Luther, or even sons (and daughters) of all tyrants. They are scared of independent thinkers, of those who do not follow the dogma of rigid religious structures. Notice how the person-hood movement uses guilt trips to get their way. "Oh that egg was a person, how bad of you to kill it."

Fell guilty and it's a gotcha."

Since you asked, I will help you. But I will first refine and refresh my brain's memory with a simple internet search.

The Commodore VIC 20 was introduced in 1980. If you were, for example, a toddler when you visited Bell Labs in 1964, you were at least college-aged when you first saw a VIC 20.
I have a question: Do you recall if the mainframe sang that song before or after the release of "2001, A Space Odyssey?" (You know that movie also featured the Picturephone.)

My dad spent his working life at Bell Labs Murray Hill. In 1964 we kids got to use the picture phone on a visit! We also enjoyed listening to a mainframe computer that "sang" A Bicycle Built for Two. Let's see... we also had a Commodore Vic 20 (help me out if you remember) at home and were taught rudimentary programming. How far we have come...as I post this from my Android phone!

Isn't the population growth the largest factor in the growing economies of TX and FL? That growth has more to do with the faster growth of the  two states Hispanic population, who both have more children and have them younger than the the median. Add in our nations increasing aged population, and you have a growth in FL and even TX too. So, Peter, to be relevant to this article, how much of TX and FL population growth is BECAUSE of state tax policies? I won't ever move my self or my business to either state, regardless of their tax policies.

No.  You are dealing with the creation of a phony nation by the British and the French for the purposes of Oil exploitation.  That you are still affect by Iraq is the fine American failure since 1970 to create an energy policy that was not based on fossil fuels; an adamant refusal to revive mass rail transport for people and goods; and a Government that spinelessly supports and subsidizes the fossil fuel industry.  If there were no need for oil all the Middle East would be irrelevant stretches of sand.

That's just wrong.  These are lifelong residents of the area who have had border security superimposed on their community.  People who move near airports do so with eyes open and palms up.  Geogrpahic proximity is not sufficient to justify a stop absent some other factor, even a pretextual one.  And this police power can't be used simply for deterrence.  By placing everyone under suspicion at all times, the Border Patrol is sowing alienation from these residents.  If they really want cooperation from citizens, they would enlist their support.  Casting an umbrella of suspicion will have the opposite effect.  And by the way, I'd like to know the 'hit rate' - how many illegals they catch, how many tons of drugs or caches of firearms.  Not many, I would guess.

Let's try it as an experiment.  Maybe the overall situation will be better.  Unemployment costs will go down; with jobs begging people can be forced off welfare and into the workforce.  The impact of kids seeing parents with regular jobs, and parents realizing that they either must unionize or stay in school to live better might have unexpectedly beneficial side effects.  All the jobs that aliens do used to be done by citizens.  Let's try!

I can see a rationale behind the border checkpoints inland. People crossing the border along the desert and away from roads would eventually seek a ride on a road miles inside the border. That would explain the brief stop and viewing inside the vehicle.

The purpose is to teach Americans some subservience and show them who is boss.

This isn't border control. The border is south of there.

There is growing evidence that thoughout the country, Border Patrol agents sometimes participate in enforcement actions merely because of the belief that making an operation a CBP operation enables them to ask anything, search anything.

They have recently been engaging in the act of stopping and searching private aircraft that never left the country or even got close to the border. Their response to Aircraft owners and US Congressmen inquiring about it was first to deny it and then to claim that they can do what they want. Finally they agreed to some limits.

This is not about immigration at all.

This has nothing to do with immigration or anti-immigration.  It is about the arrogance of federal law enforcement and their disdain for civilians, civil rights, and the desire to put the American individual in his "proper place" vis-a-vis authority.

This is no more "unconstitutional" than DUI checkpoints.  All stops without probable cause should violate the constitution.  We live in a police state and a great many people seem to prefer it that way.

Susan, this entire theatrical enterprise is about jobs and money. Jobs for increased numbers of border agents, their supervisors, the people who fix their cars, etc. the money goes to big companies that manufacture weapons, kevlar vests, and all manner of other accoutrements. This is all part of the security theater like TSA, all designed to make people think the government has some handle on illegal immigrants or the war on drugs - both of which are failures.
Exactly.  So they just drive around the checkpoint.
It might be possible that the mere presence of the checkpoints deters illegals from attempting passage there.

Ultimately, the question is what kind of society do we wish to have? A society organized around principles of liberty and the free movement of people, goods, services and investment? Even if having such a society also means that we also suffer some ill consequences that would not be tolerated in a more authoritarian society?

Or do we wish to have a repressive, militarized society in which we place top priority on controlling everyone's identity, movements and activities? Is the price of such a place that we lose our liberties and also much of our prosperity, since closed societies invariably fare much worse than open ones?

I am adamant an unchecked invasion of illegal immigrants pouring into our nation, chocking services and preventing others from being helped who need it, too.  I think their homelands need to be sustainable so immigration is not the answer.  I think helping them there is the solution.  The U.S. is at a tipping point.  Are we a sovereign nation. or captive to millions of illegal aliens who trespass our borders?  For the record, I have stood up to racism and antisemitism, and have lost "friends."  We who oppose illegal immigration are NOT heartless monsters.

Not just the border control.  My own experience has been respectful courteous search by foreign airport security followed immediately by rude disdainful barking of orders and arrogant bullying by TSA upon arrival in the good old USA.  It is uniformed federal employees in general that are out of control.  Over paid and over-empowered.  Recall the arrogance of Park service employees in barricading roadside overlooks--all just to inconvenience the serfs as much as possible to punish them for daring to question fulfilling the federal beasts demands for ever increasing revenue.
The VA was a shining example of excellent government until the day President Obama took office, eh?

The supreme court ruled random stops are allowed but random doesn't mean stopping everyone. The justification that "anyone could be a smuggler, so everyone must be stopped" is bogus, it equates to everyone is a suspect and we'll do our best to arrest you for something. Asking questions about who owns the car, what your agenda is, etc. is way beyond the scope of their mission. That being said, you can't appreciate what they're up against unless you've seen it first hand.
I hike and hunt near Arivaca frequently. The Buenos Aires wildlife refuge is a vast, beautiful place full of garbage left by smugglers and illegals. People regularly die in the desert trying to get themselves or their contraband to Tucson or Phoenix. Some are armed, they're all very organized. I see agents out in the field day in and day out, when it's 17 degrees or 107, as it has been this past few weeks. The terrain is difficult to nearly impossible, there's always something that wants to stick, sting, cut or bite you. It's also a mountain lion habitat. Then there's the western diamondback rattlers, lots of them. I know folks who've lost pets and livestock to snakes, coyotes and lions. Agents have been killed in pursuit of smugglers.
I might feel differently if I had to go through it every day, but a 2 minute stop, a quick look over, and a question about my dog's citizenship is the worst I've encountered, and this is with a firearm visible on my hip. Then again, I'm old, white and have veterans plates.

Hey, Omaha, why not move down to the border for a bit, then "we" will take you more seriously. Doubt if you have lots of border agents setting up roadblocks in Nebraska.

Now DUI administrative roadblocks, that's similar wine in a different bottle. How do you like them?

Except they are not stopping any illegal immigration at all. And this president has deported more than Bush did in two terms and has doubled at least the border patrol. So if Bush had done his job, maybe it wouldn't have been so bad. Unfortunately we can't complain to the lousy job the last president did.
Your post does not make sense. This iS enforcement of those laws. This is what border protection looks like.

We should have more of these checkpoints so illegal immigrants do not reach the interior of the United States, because when they do, we have to support them for the rest of their lives with healthcare, schooling for the children and free lunches, teach them English, etc., time to stop illegal immigration and if these checkpoints will do it, we must put up with them!  If your President would enforce our immigration laws, these things would not happen, so complain to him, he is the problem?
Your airport analogy is flawed. Many people have lived along the border for generations.  The intrusive border checkpoints came to them, not the other way around.
